All, all, all, all, all, all, all, all, all, all, all right, all right

This part sounds a lot like sexual moaning (and there’s some heavy breathing thrown in there too), alluding to the previous lines. During this time, the particular fascination with Maoism went hand-in-hand with the sexual revolution; John Lennon is mocking young middle-class protestors who embraced Maoism because it was “trendy” and might get them laid, not for their own beliefs.
You ain’t gonna make it with anyone anyhow

This line has a double meaning:


If you support violent revolution in the style of Chairman Mao you will fail in your efforts to overthrow the system.
If you think it is cool to play radical and carry around pictures of Chairman Mao,
You aren’t going to get laid. (Your faux revolution isn’t fooling anyone.)

You say you want a revolution
 Well, you know

1968 was a year of social unrest. On the day of the first recording sessions for this song, French president Charles De Gaulle dissolved the French assembly and called an election. This was in response to a month of sustained protest by young, left-wing radicals, as well as strikes and occupations at factories and universities. At the peak of the protest, nearly a quarter of the French workforce was on strike.



The year also saw 100,000 people march on the US embassy on London to protest against the Vietnam war. British students were also copying their French counterparts with sit-down protests at universities.

The atmosphere was not remotely the same as when the Beatles recorded All You Need Is Love the previous year. Symbolically, peaceful protests were dealt a hammer blow by the assassination of Dr Martin Luther King Jnr., the senior figure in the Civil Rights movement and a strong advocate of peaceful protest.

Don’t you know it’s gonna be all right
 Don’t you know it’s gonna be all right
 Don’t you know it’s gonna be all right

Everything’s going to be fine – there’s no need for violent revolution.

While the world is far from “alright”, the Beatles did impart the gift of freedom of music and art into the bleak Soviet proletariat’s life. Hunter Davies credited the fall of the Soviet Union, in part, to the Beatles exposing the young Soviets to Western culture.

This has to be taken slowly, but the theory is young Russians preferred Lennon to Lenin, liked listening to Beatles lyrics and music rather than political dogma. Ergo, they refused to consider Western culture as decadent and Westerners as the enemy, and grew cynical about their own Communist propaganda.
- Hunter Davies, The Beatles
We all wanna change the world

In this interview, John expresses how he believes the world was being run by “maniacs”. It’s not that he embraced the world communist ideology, any more than democracy, but, he saw injustice throughout the world.





In this line, he’s saying, that he’s not alone at seeing the inequality of the sexes, the subjugation of the masses, the unfair distribution of wealth, and the suffering that millions endure. However, it’s not an easy fix.



Throw down one government, and the same government rises up, often with worse leadership, like it did in the Soviet Union.

So, he came to believe in “revolution,” as a term of art, in social consciousness, not bloody insurrection. Change begins within each person, with an awareness of the world around them, with empathy, and respect, for every living thing.

He was trying to get people to look inwards. This is what other great religious leaders have done, like Jesus and Buddha.

I would categorize his revolution more in league with seeking a new religion, than overthrowing governments.
You tell me that it’s evolution

“Evolution” is a biological term, originating with Charles Darwin, not a term associated with sociological rhetoric.

Evolution is also associated with a theory formulated by polymath professor, Herbert Spensor, “Survival of the fittest.”

In interviews, he claimed that the reason he supported some revolutionary causes was because, he “hated the status quo.”



Evolution, in this setting, describes building the strongest society, where it is considered a single organism, which cannot afford to maintain those who are not able to contribute:
.
We all wanna change the world

During this period, after meeting Yoko, John did meet with well-known radicals, and some Trotskyite.



In his documentary, “John Lennon’s Revolution,” John Leaf and John Sheinfeld said:


The two came in contact with leaders of the movement in Britain–significantly, Ali and Robin Blackburn, both members of the Trotskyist International Marxist Group. A later interview/discussion among the four that appeared in the IMG paper Red Mole (reprinted in Ali’s memoir Streetfighting Years)–gives a sense of the back-and-forth about the questions facing the struggle.

John’s song “Revolution” on the Beatles' White Album is a reflection of such discussions. It famously says that “you can count me out,” but this is a comment on tactics–specifically, the role of violence in the struggle.
But if you go carrying pictures

Back in the days of McCarthyism in America, people were blacklisted by being called “card carrying communists.” Lennon is talking about people advocating for communism. In particular, this is a reference to “The Little Red Book”, a popular collection of the sayings of Mao Zedong. It had a picture of Mao on the cover.

You ask me for a contribution
 Well, you know
 We’re all doing what we can

Even revolutionaries need cash to run their protests and get their message out.  John says: it’s about what you do and say in your life, fundraising isn’t enough.

Also being as he was insanely rich, everyone asked John for money.



They undoubtedly wanted his support to reach the generation who idolized him, as well. The value of him acting out and speaking about revolutionary ideals jettisoned their cause by light years.



When they ask him for “contributions,” he doesn’t say, “no way,” he says:

“WE’RE DOING WHAT WE CAN!”

You say you got a real solution
 Well, you know
 We’d all love to see the plan
John cleverly mocking all the radicals that said they had a solution to all the world’s ills. He’s calling them out, asking to actually see those plans before he donates money or advocates violence.
